So they will be responsible for filing that on March 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is, briefly, some First Amendment cases that we're involved in.
We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco we have the Bay Area Reporter,
are being censored at a number of prisons around the country.
the country. Prisoners who want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not
being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit
probably with a lot of the Congressional Correctional Institute in Kentucky and
maybe one here at the Lompoc prison and possibly one down in Texas as well.
Then last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students. I went to, well I went to several

undergraduate schools. I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes, and as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events, and Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections.
We wanted to put up a banner that said, Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared,
because we found out from some of our sources, close to the administration,
that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year,
because they were probably in some pretty serious trouble.
So the next year, we made an application to put up the banner and ended up without any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971,
last year they allowed that gay students be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school, another school mission called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they allege they're gay.
There's a private college in the suburb of Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework,
and so this person's gay, and he doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools, and he can't handle his degree.
We find at the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has official,
grant official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any of the benefits
that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now
involving the rights of students
to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big Bay rights case
before I came to the West Coast involved in the lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.,
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate until the law school gave student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students, as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California. It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections and people to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about.
It's writing these new laws about diversity in the country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality?
because that seems to be something in California
that is sort of an issue and it's very complicated.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take
is we basically wait for people to come to us,
which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If the data doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call so they can think about some kind of discrimination or adverse action.
But, that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
The thing that you do talk about is in housing,
screenwriters have been pointing out that this city, Denver,
has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together.
And this is often used against gay couples.
We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright
as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay,
but was intended to keep noise down
and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly didn't have an impact on the day to day.
Some of the guys like that, it's very subtle
with the legislation.
Some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.
